## 21. Confidential Information and Non-Disclosure

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This is a comprehensive, "pro-discloser" legal clause suitable for a Master Services Agreement (MSA), Employment Contract, or high-stakes Partnership Agreement. It is designed to be dense, restrictive, and protective of proprietary interests.\n\n***\n\n### 21. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION AND NON-DISCLOSURE\n\n**21.1 Definition of Confidential Information.** For the purposes of this Agreement, “Confidential Information” shall mean any and all non-public, proprietary, or sensitive information, whether or not marked as “confidential” or “proprietary,” disclosed by one party (the “Disclosing Party”) to the other party (the “Receiving Party”), whether orally, in writing, or by inspection of tangible objects, and whether disclosed before or after the Effective Date. Confidential Information includes, without limitation: (a) technical data, trade secrets, know-how, formulae, designs, concepts, schematics, drawings, algorithms, software code (source and object), and research and development materials; (b) business plans, marketing strategies, customer lists, vendor lists, pricing policies, financial statements, and projections; (c) any information regarding the Disclosing Party’s employees, contractors, or internal organizational structure; and (d) the existence and specific terms and conditions of this Agreement.\n\n**21.2 Exclusions.** Confidential Information shall not include information that the Receiving Party can demonstrate by written documentation: (a) was already known to the Receiving Party without restriction at the time of disclosure; (b) is or becomes generally available to the public through no fault or breach of this Agreement by the Receiving Party; (c) is rightfully received by the Receiving Party from a third party who is not under a duty of confidentiality; or (d) is independently developed by the Receiving Party without use of or reference to the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information.\n\n**21.3 Obligations of Non-Use and Non-Disclosure.** The Receiving Party shall: (a) maintain the Confidential Information in strict confidence and take all reasonable precautions to prevent its unauthorized dissemination, using at least the same degree of care as it uses to protect its own confidential information of a similar nature, but in no event less than a reasonable standard of care; (b) use the Confidential Information solely for the purpose of exercising its rights and performing its obligations under this Agreement (the “Purpose”); and (c) not disclose, divulge, or otherwise communicate any Confidential Information to any third party, except to its employees, legal counsel, or financial advisors (collectively, “Representatives”) who have a legitimate “need to know” such information for the Purpose and who are bound by confidentiality obligations at least as restrictive as those contained herein. The Receiving Party shall be liable for any breach of this Section 21 by its Representatives.\n\n**21.4 Compelled Disclosure.** If the Receiving Party is required by law, regulation, or a valid order of a court or other governmental body to disclose Confidential Information, the Receiving Party shall, to the extent legally permitted: (a) provide the Disclosing Party with prompt written notice of such requirement so that the Disclosing Party may seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy; (b) limit the disclosure to only that portion of the Confidential Information which is legally required; and (c) exercise reasonable efforts to obtain assurance that confidential treatment will be accorded to the information so disclosed.\n\n**21.5 Return or Destruction of Materials.** Upon the Disclosing Party’s written request, or upon the expiration or termination of this Agreement for any reason, the Receiving Party shall promptly, and at the Disclosing Party’s option, either return all originals and copies of Confidential Information in its possession or control, or destroy the same and certify such destruction in writing. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Receiving Party may retain: (i) such copies of Confidential Information as are required to be maintained by law or regulation; and (ii) Confidential Information contained in archived computer system backups, provided that such retained information shall remain subject to the confidentiality obligations of this Agreement until such time as it is destroyed in the ordinary course of business.\n\n**21.6 Ownership and No License.** All Confidential Information remains the sole and exclusive property of the Disclosing Party. Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as granting any rights, by license or otherwise, to any Confidential Information, or to any invention, patent, copyright, trademark, or other intellectual property right of the Disclosing Party.\n\n**21.7 Remedies and Equitable Relief.** The Receiving Party acknowledges that any breach or threatened breach of this Section 21 may cause irreparable harm to the Disclosing Party for which monetary damages would be an inadequate remedy. Accordingly, in the event of such a breach or threatened breach, the Disclosing Party shall be entitled to seek, in addition to any other available remedies at law or in equity, immediate injunctive relief and specific performance, without the necessity of posting a bond or proving actual damages.\n\n**21.8 Survival.** The obligations of confidentiality, non-use, and non-disclosure set forth in this Section 21 shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement for a period of five (5) years; provided, however, that with respect to any Confidential Information that constitutes a trade secret under applicable law, such obligations shall survive for as long as such information remains a trade secret.\n\n***\n\n### Key Legal Elements included:\n*   **Breadth of Scope:** Covers both tangible and intangible data, as well as the existence of the contract itself.\n*   **Standard of Care:** Establishes the "reasonable care" threshold while tethering it to the party\'s own internal standards.\n*   **Compelled Disclosure Protections:** Provides a "notice-and-cooperate" workflow for subpoenas.\n*   **Safe Harbor for Backups:** Recognizes the reality of modern IT (archived digital backups) while maintaining the duty to protect them.\n*   **Equitable Relief:** Explicitly mentions "irreparable harm" to make it easier to get a court-ordered injunction if secrets are leaked.\n*   **Trade Secret Extension:** Ensures that while general secrets expire (e.g., 5 years), core trade secrets are protected in perpetuity.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 22. Exceptions to Confidentiality

[{'type': 'text', 'text': '**22. EXCEPTIONS TO CONFIDENTIALITY**\n\n**22.1. General Exclusions.** Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the obligations of confidentiality, non-use, and non-disclosure set forth herein shall not apply to any information, data, or materials for which the Receiving Party can demonstrate, through competent contemporaneous written evidence, that such information:\n(a) was already in the public domain at the time of its disclosure by the Disclosing Party or subsequently becomes part of the public domain through no fault, act, or omission of the Receiving Party, its Affiliates, or their respective Representatives in violation of this Agreement;\n(b) was rightfully in the Receiving Party’s possession, free of any obligation of confidence, prior to the time of disclosure by the Disclosing Party;\n(c) was lawfully obtained by the Receiving Party from a third party who, to the Receiving Party’s knowledge after reasonable inquiry, was not under an obligation of confidentiality to the Disclosing Party and had the legal right to disclose such information; or\n(d) was independently developed by the Receiving Party or its Affiliates without the use of, reference to, or reliance upon the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information, as evidenced by the Receiving Party’s internal records maintained in the ordinary course of business.\n\n**22.2. Compelled Disclosure.** \n(a) **Legal Process:** The Receiving Party may disclose Confidential Information to the extent required by a valid order of a court of competent jurisdiction, a government agency, or other applicable legal, administrative, or regulatory process (a “Legal Requirement”). \n(b) **Notice and Cooperation:** In the event the Receiving Party is subject to a Legal Requirement to disclose Confidential Information, the Receiving Party shall, to the extent legally permissible: (i) provide the Disclosing Party with prompt written notice of such requirement so that the Disclosing Party may seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy; (ii) reasonably cooperate with the Disclosing Party, at the Disclosing Party’s sole expense, in opposing such disclosure or seeking a protective order; and (iii) only disclose that portion of the Confidential Information that it is legally compelled to disclose based on the advice of its legal counsel.\n(c) **Protective Treatment:** If, in the absence of a protective order, the Receiving Party is nonetheless legally compelled to disclose Confidential Information, the Receiving Party shall exercise commercially reasonable efforts to obtain assurance that confidential treatment will be accorded to the disclosed information.\n\n**22.3. Permitted Disclosures to Representatives.** The Receiving Party may disclose the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information to its and its Affiliates’ directors, officers, employees, legal counsel, accountants, and financial advisors (collectively, “Representatives”) strictly on a “need-to-know” basis for the purposes of performing its obligations or exercising its rights under this Agreement. The Receiving Party shall: (a) ensure that all such Representatives are informed of the confidential nature of the information; (b) ensure that such Representatives are bound by written confidentiality obligations at least as restrictive as those contained herein; and (c) remain primarily liable for any breach of this Agreement caused by the acts or omissions of its Representatives.\n\n**22.4. Statutory Immunity (U.S. Defend Trade Secrets Act).** Pursuant to the Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 (18 U.S.C. § 1833(b)), the Receiving Party is hereby notified that an individual shall not be held criminally or civilly liable under any Federal or State trade secret law for the disclosure of a trade secret that: (a) is made (i) in confidence to a Federal, State, or local government official, either directly or indirectly, or to an attorney; and (ii) solely for the purpose of reporting or investigating a suspected violation of law; or (b) is made in a complaint or other document filed in a lawsuit or other proceeding, if such filing is made under seal. \n\n**22.5. Burden of Proof.** The burden of proving the applicability of any exception set forth in this Section 22 shall rest entirely upon the Receiving Party. No Confidential Information shall be deemed to be within the foregoing exceptions merely because it is embraced by more general information within the exceptions, nor shall a combination of features be deemed within the exceptions unless the combination itself and its entire principle of operation are within the exceptions.\n\n**22.6. Residuals.** Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed to limit the Receiving Party’s right to use for any purpose the "residuals" resulting from access to or work with the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information, provided that the Receiving Party does not disclose the Confidential Information except as permitted herein. The term “residuals” means information in non-tangible form which may be retained in the unaided memory of persons who have had access to the Confidential Information, including ideas, concepts, know-how, or techniques contained therein, so long as such persons have not intentionally memorized the Confidential Information for the purpose of circumventing the restrictions of this Agreement. This Section 22.6 does not grant the Receiving Party any license under any patents or copyrights of the Disclosing Party.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 23. Data Protection and Privacy Compliance (DPA)

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This text is drafted as a robust, enterprise-grade legal clause suitable for a Master Service Agreement (MSA), SaaS Agreement, or complex Data Processing Agreement. It is designed to be "dense and detailed" as requested, covering multiple jurisdictions (GDPR, UK GDPR, CCPA/CPRA) and standard commercial protections.\n\n***\n\n### 23. Data Protection and Privacy Compliance (DPA)\n\n**23.1 Definitions and Scope.** For the purposes of this Section 23, the terms “Personal Data,” “Data Subject,” “Processing,” “Controller,” “Processor,” and “Personal Data Breach” shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”) or other applicable Data Protection Laws. “Data Protection Laws” shall mean all applicable global laws and regulations relating to the processing of personal data and privacy, including but not limited to the GDPR, the UK GDPR, the California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 (as amended by the California Privacy Rights Act of 2020) (“CCPA”), and any other local, state, or federal privacy statutes enacted in the jurisdictions where the Parties operate.\n\n**23.2 Roles of the Parties.** The Parties acknowledge and agree that with respect to the Processing of Personal Data provided by the Customer (the “Controller”) to the Provider (the “Processor”) in connection with the Services, the Provider acts as a Processor (or “Service Provider” as defined under the CCPA). The scope, nature, and purpose of the Processing, the types of Personal Data, and the categories of Data Subjects are set forth in the [Data Processing Addendum/Schedule] attached hereto, which is incorporated by reference.\n\n**23.3 Compliance Obligations.** The Processor represents and warrants that it shall:\n(a) Process Personal Data only on documented instructions from the Controller, including with regard to transfers of Personal Data to a third country or an international organization, unless required to do so by applicable law;\n(b) Ensure that persons authorized to Process the Personal Data have committed themselves to confidentiality or are under an appropriate statutory obligation of confidentiality;\n(c) Implement and maintain rigorous technical and organizational measures (“TOMs”) to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk, including, as appropriate, the pseudonymization and encryption of data, the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems, and a process for regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of such measures;\n(d) Assist the Controller, taking into account the nature of the Processing, by appropriate technical and organizational measures, insofar as this is possible, for the fulfillment of the Controller’s obligation to respond to requests for exercising the Data Subject\'s rights;\n(e) Assist the Controller in ensuring compliance with the obligations pursuant to Articles 32 to 36 of the GDPR (Security, Breach Notification, DPIA, and Prior Consultation) taking into account the nature of processing and the information available to the Processor.\n\n**23.4 Sub-processing.** The Processor shall not engage another processor (a “Sub-processor”) without prior specific or general written authorization of the Controller. In the case of general written authorization, the Processor shall inform the Controller of any intended changes concerning the addition or replacement of Sub-processors, thereby giving the Controller the opportunity to object to such changes. The Processor shall impose the same data protection obligations as set out in this Section 23 on any Sub-processor by way of a written contract, and the Processor shall remain fully liable to the Controller for the performance of that Sub-processor\'s obligations.\n\n**23.5 International Data Transfers.** To the extent that the Processing of Personal Data involves a transfer from the European Economic Area (EEA), Switzerland, or the United Kingdom to a country that has not been deemed to provide an adequate level of protection by the relevant regulatory authorities, the Parties agree to rely on the standard contractual clauses (SCCs) approved by the European Commission or the UK International Data Transfer Addendum (IDTA), as applicable. Such clauses shall be deemed incorporated herein by reference and shall prevail in the event of a conflict with this Agreement.\n\n**23.6 Data Breach Notification.** The Processor shall notify the Controller without undue delay (and in any event within forty-eight (48) hours) after becoming aware of a Personal Data Breach. Such notification shall include, at a minimum: (i) the nature of the breach; (ii) the categories and approximate number of Data Subjects and records concerned; (iii) the name and contact details of the Data Protection Officer or other contact point; and (iv) the measures taken or proposed to be taken to mitigate the effects of the breach.\n\n**23.7 Audit Rights and Inspection.** The Processor shall make available to the Controller all information necessary to demonstrate compliance with the obligations laid down in this Section 23 and allow for and contribute to audits, including inspections, conducted by the Controller or another auditor mandated by the Controller. Any such audit shall be conducted during normal business hours, subject to reasonable prior notice, and shall not occur more than once per calendar year, except in the event of a suspected or actual Personal Data Breach.\n\n**23.8 Termination and Data Return.** Upon the termination or expiration of this Agreement, or at any time upon the Controller’s written request, the Processor shall, at the choice of the Controller, delete or return all Personal Data to the Controller and delete existing copies unless applicable law requires the storage of the Personal Data.\n\n**23.9 CCPA Specific Provisions.** To the extent the CCPA applies, the Processor certifies that it understands and will comply with the restrictions on “selling” or “sharing” Personal Information and will not retain, use, or disclose Personal Information for any purpose other than for the specific purpose of performing the Services specified in this Agreement, or as otherwise permitted by the CCPA. The Processor shall notify the Controller if it makes a determination that it can no longer meet its obligations under the CCPA.\n\n**23.10 Conflict of Terms.** In the event of any conflict or inconsistency between the terms of this Section 23 and the main body of this Agreement, the terms of this Section 23 shall prevail. If a separate Data Processing Addendum (“DPA”) is executed by the Parties, that DPA shall supersede this Section 23 to the extent of any conflict.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 24. Information Security and Security Measures

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This text is designed for a **Master Services Agreement (MSA)**, **SaaS Terms of Service**, or a **Data Processing Agreement (DPA)**. It utilizes high-level legal and technical terminology to ensure maximum protection and clarity regarding the responsibilities of a Service Provider.\n\n***\n\n### 24. Information Security and Security Measures\n\n**24.1 Technical and Organizational Measures.** The Provider represents and warrants that it has implemented, and shall maintain throughout the Term, a comprehensive written information security program (“WISP”) that complies with applicable Data Protection Laws and industry standards (e.g., ISO/IEC 27001, SOC 2 Type II, or NIST CSF). Such program shall include formal policies, procedures, and rigorous technical and organizational measures (“TOMs”) designed to: (a) ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services; (b) protect against unauthorized or unlawful access, accidental loss, destruction, damage, or disclosure of Customer Data; and (c) identify and mitigate foreseeable internal and external risks to the security of the Provider’s network and information systems.\n\n**24.2 Access Control and Authentication.** Provider shall strictly limit access to Customer Data to those personnel who have a legitimate "need-to-know" for the performance of the Services. Provider shall maintain robust identity and access management (IAM) protocols, including, but not limited to: (i) the principle of least privilege (PoLP); (ii) the use of multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all remote and administrative access; (iii) immediate revocation of access credentials upon employee termination or change in role; and (iv) periodic reviews of access rights.\n\n**24.3 Encryption and Data Protection.** Provider shall employ industry-standard cryptographic protocols to protect Customer Data. All data shall be encrypted: (a) while in transit over public or untrusted networks using Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2 or higher; and (b) while at rest using AES-256 or an equivalent strong encryption standard. Provider shall maintain secure key management practices to prevent unauthorized decryption or exposure of cryptographic materials.\n\n**24.4 Vulnerability Management and Network Security.** Provider shall maintain a secure network architecture including the use of stateful firewalls, intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDS/IPS), and logical segmentation of production environments from development and testing environments. Provider shall perform: (i) continuous automated vulnerability scanning; (ii) quarterly internal and external penetration testing conducted by independent, qualified third-party security professionals; and (iii) timely remediation of discovered vulnerabilities in accordance with Provider’s patch management policy, prioritized by CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) severity.\n\n**24.5 Security Incident Response.** Provider shall maintain a formal Incident Response Plan (“IRP”) to be invoked in the event of a suspected or actual Security Incident. A “Security Incident” is defined as any unauthorized access, acquisition, disclosure, or accidental destruction of Customer Data. In the event of a Security Incident, Provider shall: (a) notify the Customer without undue delay and, in any event, within forty-eight (48) hours of discovery; (b) take immediate steps to mitigate the effects and prevent further unauthorized activity; and (c) provide the Customer with a detailed report encompassing the nature of the breach, the volume of data impacted, and the remediation steps taken.\n\n**24.6 Audit Rights and Compliance Documentation.** Upon written request, and no more than once per calendar year, Provider shall provide Customer with executive summaries of its most recent independent security audit reports (e.g., SOC 2 Type II or ISO 27001 certification). If Customer has a reasonable basis to believe Provider is in material breach of its security obligations, and the provided reports are insufficient to verify compliance, Provider shall allow Customer (or a mutually agreed-upon independent third-party auditor) to conduct a targeted security assessment of Provider’s environment, subject to strict confidentiality obligations and at Customer’s sole expense.\n\n**24.7 Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery.** Provider shall maintain and regularly test a Business Continuity Plan (“BCP”) and a Disaster Recovery Plan (“DRP”) designed to minimize service disruptions. This shall include, at minimum: (i) geographically redundant data backups performed at least daily; (ii) documented Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO); and (iii) regular integrity testing of backup restoration processes to ensure data can be recovered within the specified timeframes.\n\n**24.8 Personnel Security and Training.** Provider shall ensure that all employees and contractors with access to Customer Data are subject to: (a) comprehensive background checks (to the extent permitted by local law); (b) binding confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements that survive the termination of employment; and (c) mandatory annual security awareness training, including specialized training on phishing, social engineering, and secure coding practices for development personnel.\n\n**24.9 Disposal of Data.** Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement, or upon Customer’s written request, Provider shall, at Customer’s election, either return or securely delete all Customer Data in its possession or control. Deletion shall be performed in accordance with NIST 800-88 (Guidelines for Media Sanitization) or an equivalent standard, ensuring that data is rendered unrecoverable. Provider shall, upon request, provide a written certification of such destruction.\n\n**24.10 Sub-processor Security.** To the extent that Provider engages sub-processors to process Customer Data, Provider shall ensure that such sub-processors are bound by written agreements providing a level of data protection no less protective than those set forth in this Section 24. Provider shall remain fully liable for the acts and omissions of its sub-processors regarding the security of Customer Data.\n\n***\n\n### Key Legal Phrases used:\n*   **"Without undue delay":** A standard timeframe in GDPR and other privacy laws that is more flexible than a hard hour-count but implies urgency.\n*   **"Commercially reasonable":** Limits the provider\'s liability to what is standard and feasible in the industry.\n*   **"Principle of Least Privilege":** A technical security standard often required for compliance audits.\n*   **"Sanitization":** The legal/technical term for making data permanently unrecoverable.\n*   **"Indemnification/Liability":** Usually handled in a separate section, but Section 24.10 links sub-processor failure back to the primary Provider.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 25. Security Incident Notification and Remediation

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This is a dense, legally rigorous draft for **Section 25. Security Incident Notification and Remediation**. It is designed for use in a Master Service Agreement (MSA), Data Processing Addendum (DPA), or high-level SaaS Agreement.\n\n***\n\n### 25. Security Incident Notification and Remediation\n\n**25.1 Definition of Security Incident.** For the purposes of this Agreement, a “Security Incident” shall mean any confirmed or reasonably suspected accidental, unauthorized, or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, disclosure of, or access to, Customer Data or Personal Data (as defined by Applicable Law) transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed by the Provider, its Sub-processors, or its personnel. A Security Incident shall also include any breach of the physical or technical security measures implemented by the Provider as set forth in this Agreement.\n\n**25.2 Initial Notification.** In the event that the Provider becomes aware of a Security Incident, Provider shall notify the Customer without undue delay, and in any event no later than twenty-four (24) to forty-eight (48) hours after becoming aware of such incident. Such notification shall be delivered via [specified method, e.g., email to the Customer’s designated security contact or through the administrative portal]. Initial notification shall not be delayed due to incomplete information and shall be provided based on the information then available.\n\n**25.3 Content of Notification.** The notification provided to the Customer shall, at a minimum, include:\n*   (a) A description of the nature of the Security Incident, including, where possible, the categories and approximate number of data subjects and records concerned;\n*   (b) The date and time the incident occurred and was discovered;\n*   (c) The name and contact details of the Provider’s Data Protection Officer (DPO) or other point of contact from whom further information can be obtained;\n*   (d) A preliminary assessment of the likely consequences of the Security Incident; and\n*   (e) A description of the measures taken or proposed to be taken by the Provider to address the Security Incident and mitigate its possible adverse effects.\n\n**25.4 Ongoing Updates and Cooperation.** Following the initial notification, the Provider shall provide the Customer with regular (at least daily, unless otherwise agreed) status updates regarding the progress of its investigation and remediation efforts. Provider shall cooperate fully with the Customer, and at the Customer’s request, with law enforcement and relevant regulatory authorities, to facilitate the Customer’s compliance with its own notification obligations under Applicable Law (e.g., GDPR, CCPA/CPRA, HIPAA).\n\n**25.5 Remediation and Mitigation.** Upon discovery of a Security Incident, the Provider shall immediately, at its own expense:\n*   (a) Take all necessary steps to contain, stop, and mitigate the effects of the Security Incident;\n*   (b) Conduct a comprehensive root-cause analysis and forensic investigation into the incident;\n*   (c) Implement all necessary remedial measures to prevent a recurrence of the incident; and\n*   (d) Preserve all relevant evidence, including logs, traffic data, and system images, for a period of no less than one (1) year or as required by law.\n\n**25.6 Regulatory and Public Communication.** The Provider shall not make any public statements or notify any third parties (excepting law enforcement and professional advisors under a duty of confidentiality) regarding a Security Incident that identifies or involves the Customer’s Data without the Customer’s prior written consent, unless such notification is expressly required by Applicable Law. In the event the Provider is legally compelled to make a disclosure, it shall, to the extent permitted by law, provide the Customer with prior notice and an opportunity to review and comment on the content of the disclosure.\n\n**25.7 Costs and Expenses.** If a Security Incident is caused by the Provider’s failure to maintain the security standards mandated by this Agreement or through the negligence or willful misconduct of the Provider or its Sub-processors, the Provider shall be responsible for all reasonable costs incurred by the Customer in connection with the incident. Such costs include, but are not limited to:\n*   (a) Forensic investigation and audit costs;\n*   (b) Costs of providing legally required notifications to affected data subjects, regulators, and third parties;\n*   (c) Costs of establishing a toll-free call center for affected individuals;\n*   (d) Credit monitoring and identity theft restoration services for affected individuals for a period of at least twelve (12) months; and\n*   (e) Reasonable attorneys\' fees and litigation costs.\n\n**25.8 Post-Incident Report.** Within thirty (30) days of the resolution of a Security Incident, the Provider shall provide the Customer with a detailed written report (a “Post-Mortem”) outlining the final findings of the investigation, the corrective actions taken, and the improved security protocols implemented to prevent future occurrences.\n\n**25.9 No Admission of Fault.** Notification of a Security Incident by the Provider shall not be construed as an acknowledgment or admission by the Provider of any fault, liability, or negligence with respect to the incident, unless such fault is established through the investigation.\n\n***\n\n### Key Legal Considerations for this Text:\n1.  **Strict Timelines:** The 24-48 hour window is standard for high-security environments but can be negotiated based on "discovery" vs. "suspicion."\n2.  **Notification Burden:** This draft places the burden of notification costs on the Provider if they are at fault, which is a common point of contention during negotiations.\n3.  **Preservation of Evidence:** Essential for insurance claims and potential litigation.\n4.  **Public Relations Control:** Section 25.6 ensures the Customer controls the narrative regarding their own data, preventing the Provider from "pre-empting" the news.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 27. Open Source Software Components

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This text is designed for inclusion in a Master Service Agreement (MSA), End User License Agreement (EULA), or Software as a Service (SaaS) Agreement. It is drafted with a high degree of legal density to protect the Licensor while maintaining compliance with various open-source paradigms (GPL, MIT, Apache, etc.).\n\n***\n\n### 27. Open Source Software Components\n\n**27.1 Definition and Incorporation.** The Software and/or Services may incorporate, embed, be bundled with, or otherwise utilize certain third-party software components, libraries, or modules that are subject to "open source," "free software," "copyleft," or similar licensing models (collectively, **"Open Source Components"**). For the purposes of this Agreement, Open Source Components include any software licensed under terms approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI) or any similar licensing regime, including but not limited to the GNU General Public License (GPL), GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL), Apache License, MIT License, and BSD Licenses.\n\n**27.2 Primacy of Open Source Licenses.** Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this Agreement, the use, reproduction, distribution, and modification of Open Source Components are governed solely by the respective specific license agreements, notices, and terms and conditions (the **"Open Source Licenses"**) applicable to such components. In the event of any direct conflict or inconsistency between the terms of this Agreement and the terms of an Open Source License, the terms of the Open Source License shall prevail and control, but solely with respect to the specific Open Source Components to which they apply.\n\n**27.3 Disclosure and Documentation.** Licensor shall, upon written request or via a designated electronic repository (such as a `NOTICE` file, `CREDITS` file, or a "Legal" sub-directory within the Software’s installation directory), provide Licensee with a comprehensive list of all Open Source Components utilized in the then-current version of the Software, together with the applicable Open Source Licenses or links thereto. To the extent an Open Source License requires the Licensor to provide the source code for a specific Open Source Component, Licensor hereby offers to provide such source code upon written request, subject to the terms of the applicable Open Source License.\n\n**27.4 Warranty Disclaimer for Open Source Components.** LICENSEE ACKNOWLEDGES AND AGREES THAT ALL OPEN SOURCE COMPONENTS ARE PROVIDED BY LICENSOR ON AN **"AS IS"** AND **"AS AVAILABLE"** BASIS, WITHOUT ANY REPRESENTATIONS, WARRANTIES, OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, EITHER EXPRESS, IMPLIED, OR STATUTORY. TO THE MAXIMUM EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW, LICENSOR EXPRESSLY DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES REGARDING OPEN SOURCE COMPONENTS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO ANY WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE, TITLE, NON-INFRINGEMENT, AND ANY WARRANTIES ARISING FROM A COURSE OF DEALING, USAGE, OR TRADE PRACTICE. PROVIDER DOES NOT WARRANT THAT THE SERVICES WILL BE ENTIRELY ERROR-FREE OR UNINTERRUPTED, EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY PROVIDED IN THE SLA.\n\n**29.9 Survival of Warranties.** All representations and warranties made by Provider in this Section 29 shall survive the execution and delivery of this Agreement and the completion of the Services or the termination/expiration of this Agreement for the maximum duration permitted by the applicable statute of limitations.\n\n***\n\n### Key Legal Elements included:\n*   **The "Workmanlike" Standard:** Establishes a professional baseline for performance.\n*   **The Warranty Period:** Defines how long the provider is "on the hook" for bugs or errors.\n*   **Malicious Code Warranty:** Protects the client against cybersecurity threats introduced by the provider.\n*   **Sole and Exclusive Remedy (Tiered):** Provides a clear path for remediation (Fix -> Refund -> Terminate).\n*   **Pro-rata Refunds:** Ensures the client doesn\'t pay for services they can\'t use.\n*   **Disclaimer (The "As-Is" Carve-out):** Protects the provider from unrealistic expectations of 100% uptime or perfection, which is standard in tech law.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

For the avoidance of doubt, the indemnification obligations set forth in this Section 33 are independent of, and shall not be capped by, any general limitation of liability set forth elsewhere in this Agreement, unless such limitation of liability expressly refers to this Section 33.\n\n**33.5 Exclusive Remedy.** While this Section 33 sets forth the Customer\'s financial responsibility for third-party claims, it does not preclude the Company from seeking any other cumulative remedies available at law or in equity for direct damages arising from Customer’s breach of this Agreement.\n\n**33.6 Survival.** The provisions of this Section 33 shall survive the expiration or earlier termination of this Agreement for any reason and shall remain in full force and effect until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations for any Claim subject to indemnification hereunder.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 34. Indemnification Procedures and Conduct of Claims

[{'type': 'text', 'text': '**34. INDEMNIFICATION PROCEDURES AND CONDUCT OF CLAIMS**\n\n**34.1 Notice of Claim.** If any party entitled to indemnification under this Agreement (the "Indemnified Party") receives notice of the assertion or commencement of any claim, demand, action, suit, proceeding, or investigation (each, a "Claim") by a third party for which the other party (the "Indemnifying Party") is obligated to provide indemnification, the Indemnified Party shall provide the Indemnifying Party with reasonably prompt written notice thereof (a "Claim Notice"). Such Claim Notice shall, to the extent then known: (a) describe the Claim in reasonable detail; (b) include copies of all material notices and documents (including court papers) received by the Indemnified Party; and (c) state the estimated amount of the Losses (to the extent quantifiable) and the specific basis for the Indemnified Party’s entitlement to indemnification. The failure to provide a Claim Notice in a timely manner shall not relieve the Indemnifying Party of its obligations hereunder, except and only to the extent that the Indemnifying Party demonstrates that the defense of such Claim has been materially and irremediably prejudiced by the Indemnified Party\'s failure or delay in providing such notice.\n\n**34.2 Assumption of Defense.** The Indemnifying Party shall have the right, exercisable by written notice to the Indemnified Party within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of the Claim Notice, to assume the sole control of the defense, negotiation, and settlement of such Claim at the Indemnifying Party’s sole cost and expense, utilizing legal counsel of its selection, provided such counsel is reasonably acceptable to the Indemnified Party. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Indemnifying Party shall not be entitled to assume or maintain control of the defense of any Claim if: (i) the Claim seeks an injunction, specific performance, or other equitable relief against the Indemnified Party; (ii) the Indemnified Party has been advised by legal counsel that a conflict of interest exists between the Indemnified Party and the Indemnifying Party that would make separate representation necessary under applicable professional standards; (iii) the Claim involves criminal allegations; or (iv) the Indemnifying Party fails to diligently prosecute the defense of the Claim.\n\n**34.3 Participation and Separate Counsel.** If the Indemnifying Party elects to assume the defense of a Claim, the Indemnified Party shall have the right, at its own expense, to participate in the defense and to employ separate counsel to monitor the proceedings. However, if the Indemnifying Party is prohibited from assuming the defense pursuant to Section 34.2, or if the Indemnifying Party fails to timely assume the defense, the Indemnified Party may defend the Claim in any manner it deems appropriate at the Indemnifying Party’s sole cost and expense. In such event, the Indemnifying Party shall reimburse the Indemnified Party for its reasonable legal fees and costs on a monthly basis.\n\n**34.4 Settlement of Claims.**\n(a) *By the Indemnifying Party:* The Indemnifying Party shall not enter into any settlement, compromise, or consent to the entry of any judgment regarding a Claim without the prior written consent of the Indemnified Party (which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed), unless the settlement: (i) involves only the payment of monetary damages for which the Indemnifying Party is fully liable; (ii) includes an unconditional release of the Indemnified Party from all liability in respect of the Claim; and (iii) does not include any admission of wrongdoing, culpability, or a failure to act by or on behalf of the Indemnified Party, nor imposes any ongoing obligation or restrictive covenant upon the Indemnified Party.\n(b) *By the Indemnified Party:* If the Indemnifying Party has assumed the defense, the Indemnified Party shall not settle or compromise any Claim without the prior written consent of the Indemnifying Party. If the Indemnifying Party has failed or refused to assume the defense, the Indemnified Party may settle the Claim on such terms as it deems fit, and the Indemnifying Party shall remain liable for the resulting Losses, provided the settlement is commercially reasonable.\n\n**34.5 Cooperation.** The parties shall cooperate in good faith in the defense or prosecution of any third-party Claim. Such cooperation shall include, without limitation: (a) the retention and (upon the other party\'s request) the provision of records and information reasonably relevant to the Claim; (b) making employees and agents available on a mutually convenient basis to provide additional information and explanation of any material provided hereunder or to serve as witnesses; and (c) providing access to properties and facilities. The Indemnified Party shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate any Losses for which it seeks indemnification, provided that all costs of mitigation shall themselves constitute Indemnified Losses.\n\n**34.6 Direct Claims.** In the event an Indemnified Party has a claim against the Indemnifying Party that does not involve a third-party Claim (a "Direct Claim"), the Indemnified Party shall deliver a written notice to the Indemnifying Party describing the Direct Claim in reasonable detail, the amount of the estimated Losses, and the basis for the claim. If the Indemnifying Party does not notify the Indemnified Party within thirty (30) days that it disputes the Direct Claim, the amount of such Losses shall be deemed conclusively established and the Indemnifying Party shall pay such amount on demand. If the Indemnifying Party disputes the Direct Claim within such thirty-day period, the parties shall attempt in good faith to resolve the dispute for a period of thirty (30) days prior to initiating any formal legal proceedings.\n\n**34.7 Subrogation.** Upon the payment in full of any indemnification amount for a third-party Claim, the Indemnifying Party shall be subrogated to the extent of such payment to every right of recovery the Indemnified Party may have against third parties with respect to the matters to which such payment relates. The Indemnified Party shall execute and deliver all instruments and papers required and do whatever else is necessary to secure such rights and shall provide reasonable assistance (at the Indemnifying Party’s expense) to enable the Indemnifying Party to exercise such rights.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 35. Limitation of Liability: Direct Damages Cap

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This is a dense, legally robust draft of a **Direct Damages Cap** section, suitable for high-stakes commercial contracts (such as SaaS agreements, Master Service Agreements, or complex licensing deals).\n\n***\n\n### 35. Limitation of Liability: Direct Damages Cap\n\n**35.1. Aggregate Financial Limitation.** Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, and to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law, the total, cumulative, and aggregate liability of either Party (including their respective Affiliates, directors, officers, employees, agents, and subcontractors) arising out of or in connection with this Agreement, the performance or contemplated performance of the Services, or any Order Form issued hereunder—whether such liability arises from any claim based upon contract, warranty, tort (including negligence, whether active, passive, or imputed), strict liability, product liability, professional errors or omissions, contribution, or any other legal or equitable theory—shall not exceed, in the aggregate, the total amounts actually paid by Customer to Provider under the specific Order Form giving rise to the claim during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date on which the event first giving rise to the liability occurred (the “Direct Damages Cap”).\n\n**35.2. Multiplicity of Claims.** The existence of one or more claims shall not enlarge or extend the Direct Damages Cap. Customer acknowledges and agrees that the Direct Damages Cap shall apply regardless of whether any remedy set forth herein fails of its essential purpose. In no event shall the Provider’s total liability for all claims arising under this Agreement in its entirety exceed the total fees paid by Customer to Provider during the term of this Agreement.\n\n**35.3. Exclusions from the Cap.** The limitations of liability set forth in Section 35.1 shall not apply to, and no cap shall be placed upon, a Party’s liability resulting from:\n*   **(a)** death or personal injury caused by a Party’s negligence;\n*   **(b)** acts of fraud, fraudulent misrepresentation, or willful misconduct;\n*   **(c)** Customer’s obligation to pay undisputed fees, expenses, or taxes due under Section [X] of this Agreement;\n*   **(d)** breach of the confidentiality obligations set forth in Section [X], excluding claims related to Data Breaches (which shall be governed by the specific Super-Cap defined in Section 35.4, if applicable); or\n*   **(e)** a Party’s express indemnification obligations under Section [X] (Intellectual Property Indemnity).\n\n**35.4. Specific Super-Cap for Data Privacy.** [Optional/Negotiated Clause] Notwithstanding Section 35.1, but subject to the exclusions in Section 35.3, any liability arising from a Party’s breach of its obligations under Section [X] (Data Protection/Privacy) or the Data Processing Addendum (DPA) shall be subject to a separate aggregate limit equal to two times (2x) the Direct Damages Cap (the “Data Privacy Super-Cap”). For the avoidance of doubt, the Data Privacy Super-Cap shall be the maximum total liability for such breaches and shall not be in addition to the Direct Damages Cap, but shall encompass it.\n\n**35.5. Allocation of Risk.** The Parties acknowledge and agree that the pricing for the Services provided under this Agreement has been set in express reliance upon the limitations of liability and the allocation of risk set forth in this Section 35. The Parties further agree that these limitations are reasonable and constitute an essential basis of the bargain between the Parties, and that the Services would not have been provided in the absence of such limitations.\n\n**35.6. Statute of Limitations.** To the extent permitted by law, no action, regardless of form, arising out of or relating to this Agreement may be brought by either Party more than two (2) years after the cause of action has accrued, or more than two (2) years after the Party asserting the claim should have reasonably discovered the facts giving rise to the claim, whichever is earlier.\n\n**35.7. Exclusive Remedies.** The remedies expressly provided in this Agreement are the sole and exclusive remedies available to the Parties. Each Party waives any right to seek damages or other remedies that are inconsistent with the limitations set forth in this Section 35.\n\n***\n\n### Key Legal Components of this Text:\n1.  **The Formulaic Cap:** Uses a "rolling 12-month" look-back, which is the industry standard for protecting the vendor as the contract grows.\n2.  **Breadth of Theory:** Explicitly mentions "tort, negligence, and strict liability" to prevent the counterparty from circumventing the cap by suing outside of "contract law."\n3.  **The "Aggregate" Qualifier:** Ensures that the cap is a "bucket" for all claims, not a "per-incident" cap that could bankrupt a provider through multiple small breaches.\n4.  **Failure of Essential Purpose:** A standard "boilerplate" protection that ensures the cap remains even if the contract\'s primary remedy (like a refund or repair) doesn\'t work.\n5.  **The Super-Cap (Section 35.4):** Addresses the modern reality of GDPR/CCPA. Often, parties will agree to a higher cap for data breaches than for general performance issues.\n6.  **Economic Justification (Section 35.5):** This helps the clause survive a "unconscionability" challenge in court by stating the price was directly tied to the limitation of risk.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 36. Exclusion of Consequential and Indirect Damages

[{'type': 'text', 'text': '**36. EXCLUSION OF CONSEQUENTIAL AND INDIRECT DAMAGES**\n\n**36.1 General Limitation.** To the maximum extent permitted by applicable law, and notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Agreement, in no event shall either Party, its affiliates, or their respective officers, directors, employees, agents, or representatives (collectively, the "Related Parties") be liable to the other Party or any third party for any indirect, incidental, consequential, special, exemplary, or punitive damages whatsoever. This exclusion applies regardless of the form of action, whether such liability is asserted on the basis of contract, tort (including, without limitation, negligence and strict liability), breach of statutory duty, indemnity, contribution, or otherwise, even if the Party has been advised of the possibility of such damages or if such damages were reasonably foreseeable.\n\n**36.2 Specific Categories of Excluded Losses.** Without limiting the generality of Section 36.1, the Parties expressly agree that the following categories of losses are strictly excluded and shall not be recoverable under any circumstances:\n(a) **Loss of Profits and Revenue:** Any loss of actual or anticipated profits, loss of revenue, loss of business, or loss of contracts;\n(b) **Operational Losses:** Any loss of production, business interruption, loss of use, or increased cost of working;\n(c) **Data and Technology Losses:** Any loss of, damage to, or corruption of data, digital assets, or software, including the costs of data recovery or reconstruction;\n(d) **Commercial Opportunity:** Any loss of goodwill, loss of reputation, loss of opportunity, or loss of anticipated savings;\n(e) **Cost of Cover:** The cost of procurement of substitute goods, services, or technology; and\n(f) **Asset Diminution:** Any diminution in value of assets or any "multiplier" or "days-sales-outstanding" type damages.\n\n**36.3 Essential Purpose and Allocation of Risk.** The Parties acknowledge and agree that the limitations and exclusions contained in this Section 36 are a fundamental part of the basis of the bargain and reflect a negotiated allocation of risk between the Parties. The pricing and consideration set forth in this Agreement have been determined in reliance upon these limitations. These exclusions shall apply notwithstanding the failure of the essential purpose of any limited remedy provided herein.\n\n**36.4 Jurisdictional Carve-Out.** In the event that the laws of a particular jurisdiction do not permit the exclusion or limitation of certain types of damages, the liability of the Parties shall be limited to the maximum extent permitted by the laws of such jurisdiction. Nothing in this Section 36 is intended to exclude or limit liability for (i) death or personal injury caused by a Party’s negligence; (ii) fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation; or (iii) any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited by law.\n\n**36.5 Exception for Specific Obligations.** [Optional: Insert specific exceptions if applicable, e.g., "The exclusions set forth in this Section 36 shall not apply to a Party\'s indemnification obligations under Section [X] (Intellectual Property Indemnity) or damages arising from a Party’s gross negligence, willful misconduct, or intentional breach of confidentiality obligations under Section [Y]."]', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 37. Insurance Coverage Requirements

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This is a comprehensive, dense legal provision suitable for a Master Service Agreement (MSA), Construction Contract, or Commercial Lease. It is drafted to protect the interests of the party hiring the contractor/service provider (the "Company").\n\n***\n\n### 37. INSURANCE COVERAGE REQUIREMENTS\n\n**37.1 Maintenance of Coverage.** Without limiting any of the Contractor’s obligations or liabilities under this Agreement, the Contractor shall, at its sole cost and expense, procure and maintain in full force and effect during the term of this Agreement (and for such period thereafter as may be specified herein) the insurance coverages set forth in this Section 37. Such insurance shall be placed with insurers possessing an A.M. Best’s rating of no less than A- (Excellent), Financial Size Category VII, or as otherwise reasonably acceptable to the Company.\n\n**37.2 Minimum Scope and Limits of Insurance.** Contractor shall maintain the following minimum limits of liability:\n\n*   **(a) Commercial General Liability (CGL):** Insurance written on an ISO occurrence form (CG 00 01 04 13 or its equivalent) covering liability arising from premises, operations, independent contractors, products-completed operations, personal and advertising injury, and liability assumed under an insured contract. The limits of liability shall not be less than $2,000,000 per occurrence and $4,000,000 in the general aggregate. Such policy shall not contain any exclusions relating to punitive or exemplary damages, or "cross-suits" between insureds.\n*   **(b) Business Automobile Liability:** Insurance covering any auto (including owned, hired, and non-owned autos) with a limit of liability not less than $1,000,000 combined single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage.\n*   **(c) Workers’ Compensation and Employer’s Liability:** Workers’ Compensation insurance as required by the laws of the state(s) in which the services are to be performed, including "Other States" coverage. Employer’s Liability insurance shall be maintained with limits of not less than $1,000,000 each accident for bodily injury by accident, $1,000,000 each employee for bodily injury by disease, and $1,000,000 policy limit for bodily injury by disease.\n*   **(d) Professional Liability (Errors and Omissions):** Insurance appropriate to the Contractor’s profession, with limits not less than $3,000,000 per claim and $3,000,000 in the aggregate. If such policy is written on a "claims-made" basis, the Contractor warrants that any retroactive date under the policy shall precede the effective date of this Agreement and that continuous coverage will be maintained, or an extended discovery period will be exercised, for a period of three (3) years beginning from the time services under this Agreement are completed.\n*   **(e) Cyber Liability and Data Breach Insurance:** Insurance covering losses arising from a breach of data security, privacy, or unauthorized access to confidential information, including notification costs, regulatory fines, and legal defense, with limits not less than $5,000,000 per claim.\n*   **(f) Umbrella/Excess Liability:** Insurance providing excess coverage over the primary CGL, Automobile Liability, and Employer’s Liability policies, with limits of not less than $5,000,000 per occurrence and in the aggregate. The Umbrella/Excess policy shall be "follow-form" to the underlying policies and shall drop down in the event of exhaustion of underlying limits.\n\n**37.3 General Conditions and Endorsements.**\n\n*   **(a) Additional Insured Status:** The Company, its parent, subsidiaries, affiliates, and their respective directors, officers, employees, and agents (collectively, the "Company Indemnitees") shall be named as Additional Insureds under the CGL, Automobile Liability, and Umbrella/Excess Liability policies. This coverage shall be provided via ISO endorsements CG 20 10 and CG 20 37 (or their equivalents) and shall apply to both "ongoing operations" and "completed operations."\n*   **(b) Primary and Non-Contributory:** All insurance policies required hereunder (excepting Workers’ Compensation and Professional Liability) shall be primary and non-contributing with any insurance or self-insurance program maintained by the Company. Any insurance maintained by the Company shall be in excess of the Contractor’s insurance and shall not contribute with it.\n*   **(c) Waiver of Subrogation:** To the fullest extent permitted by law, Contractor hereby waives all rights of subrogation against the Company Indemnitees. Contractor shall cause its insurers to waive their rights of subrogation and to provide endorsements to this effect on all policies required herein.\n*   **(d) Separation of Insureds:** All liability policies shall contain a "Separation of Insureds" or "Severability of Interests" clause, stating that the insurance applies separately to each insured against whom a claim is made or suit is brought, except with respect to the limits of the insurer’s liability.\n\n**37.4 Notice of Cancellation or Material Change.** Contractor shall provide the Company with at least thirty (30) days’ prior written notice (and ten (10) days’ notice for non-payment of premium) of any cancellation, non-renewal, or material reduction in coverage or limits of any policy required under this Section.\n\n**37.5 Evidence of Insurance.** Prior to the commencement of any work or services, and upon each policy renewal or replacement thereafter, Contractor shall furnish the Company with Certificates of Insurance (COI) and copies of the required Additional Insured and Waiver of Subrogation endorsements. The receipt or review of any COI by the Company shall not be deemed a waiver of Contractor’s obligation to provide the insurance required by this Agreement, nor shall it be deemed a representation that the insurance provided by Contractor complies with these requirements.\n\n**37.6 Deductibles and Self-Insured Retentions (SIR).** Any deductibles or self-insured retentions must be declared to and approved by the Company. Contractor shall be solely responsible for the payment of all deductibles and SIRs. No deductible or SIR shall diminish the protection afforded to the Company Indemnitees under this Section.\n\n**37.7 Failure to Maintain Insurance.** The failure of Contractor to maintain the insurance required herein shall constitute a material breach of this Agreement. In the event of such breach, the Company may, at its sole discretion: (i) immediately terminate this Agreement for cause; (ii) withhold payments otherwise due to Contractor until evidence of compliance is provided; or (iii) procure the required insurance on behalf of Contractor and offset the cost of premiums against any sums due to Contractor.\n\n**37.8 No Limitation of Liability.** The insolvency, bankruptcy, or failure of any insurance company to pay a claim shall not relieve Contractor of its obligations. The minimum insurance limits required in this Section 37 shall not be construed to limit the Contractor’s liability or indemnification obligations under this Agreement.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 38. Term of Agreement and Renewal Mechanisms

[{'type': 'text', 'text': '**38. TERM OF AGREEMENT AND RENEWAL MECHANISMS**\n\n**38.1 Initial Term.** \nThis Agreement shall commence on the date of the final signature hereto (the "Effective Date") and shall remain in full force and effect for an initial period of [Number] ([#]) years (the "Initial Term"), unless terminated earlier in accordance with the express revocation or termination provisions set forth in Section [X] of this Agreement. The Initial Term represents a firm commitment by both Parties to the performance of their respective obligations hereunder, subject to any conditions precedent specifically enumerated in the Scope of Work or Appendices attached hereto.\n\n**38.2 Automatic Renewal (Evergreen Provision).** \nUpon the expiration of the Initial Term, this Agreement shall automatically renew for successive, consecutive periods of [Number] ([#]) months/years each (each, a "Renewal Term" and, collectively with the Initial Term, the "Term"), unless either Party provides the other Party with a formal written notice of non-renewal (a "Notice of Non-Renewal") at least [Number] ([#]) days prior to the expiration of the then-current Term. In the event a Notice of Non-Renewal is timely delivered, the Agreement shall terminate at the conclusion of the then-current Term, and the Parties shall commence the wind-down and transition procedures as stipulated in Section [Y].\n\n**38.3 Optional Renewal by Affirmative Notice.** \nIn the event that the Parties have expressly opted out of the automatic renewal mechanism in the Special Conditions, this Agreement may be extended only by the mutual written agreement of the Parties. The party seeking to extend (the "Requesting Party") must submit a written request for extension to the other party (the "Receiving Party") no later than [Number] ([#]) days prior to the expiration of the Initial Term or the then-current Renewal Term. The Receiving Party shall have [Number] ([#]) business days to accept or decline such extension in writing. Failure to respond within the stipulated timeframe shall be deemed a rejection of the renewal request, and the Agreement shall expire by its own terms.\n\n**38.4 Conditions Precedent to Renewal.** \nThe right of renewal—whether automatic or optional—is strictly contingent upon the following conditions being met at the time of renewal: (a) the Party seeking renewal (or benefiting from automatic renewal) must not be in material breach of any covenant, representation, or warranty contained herein; (b) all undisputed payments, fees, and disbursements due and owing under this Agreement must be paid in full; and (c) there must be no Change in Law or regulatory environment that renders the continued performance of the Agreement\'s subject matter illegal, commercially impracticable, or subject to prohibitive tax implications.\n\n**38.5 Adjustments to Consideration upon Renewal.** \nDuring each Renewal Term, the financial considerations, service fees, or unit prices set forth in Exhibit [A] (the "Pricing Schedule") shall be subject to an automatic upward adjustment. Such adjustment shall be calculated based on the greater of: (i) a fixed percentage increase of [Percentage]% over the rates applicable in the immediately preceding Term; or (ii) the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the [Region/Category] for the twelve-month period immediately preceding the renewal date. Any such adjustment shall be memorialized in a written "Renewal Price Notice" delivered by [Provider Party] to [Client Party] not less than [Number] days prior to the commencement of the Renewal Term.\n\n**38.6 Holdover Period.** \nIn the event that [Client/Licensee] continues to utilize the Services or retain possession of the Deliverables following the expiration of the Term without a formal renewal or extension in place, such continued use shall be deemed a "Holdover Period." During any Holdover Period, the terms and conditions of this Agreement shall continue to apply on a month-to-month basis, terminable by either party upon [Number] days’ notice, provided that the fees payable during such Holdover Period shall be equal to [150]% of the fees in effect during the final month of the preceding Term. The existence of a Holdover Period shall not be construed as a waiver of any rights or remedies available to the [Provider/Licensor] regarding the expiration of the Agreement.\n\n**38.7 Survival of Provisions.** \nThe expiration or termination of this Agreement for any reason shall not affect the validity or enforceability of any provisions which, by their nature, are intended to survive such expiration or termination. These include, but are not limited to, provisions regarding Confidentiality (Section [Z]), Indemnification (Section [AA]), Limitation of Liability (Section [BB]), Governing Law (Section [CC]), and any payment obligations accrued prior to the date of termination.\n\n**38.8 Effect of Termination on Renewals.** \nAny notice of termination for cause, as defined in Section [X], served during any Term shall immediately supersede and nullify any previously delivered Notice of Non-Renewal or pending Renewal Term. Upon termination, all rights granted to [Client/Licensee] to renew the Agreement shall be extinguished.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 39. Suspension of Services

[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'This is a comprehensive, "pro-provider" legal clause for a **Section 39. Suspension of Services**. It is designed for high-stakes commercial agreements (such as SaaS, Enterprise Software, or Managed Professional Services) where the provider needs maximum leverage to ensure payment and system security.\n\n***\n\n### 39. SUSPENSION OF SERVICES\n\n**39.1. Right to Suspend.** Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this Agreement, the Company reserves the right, in its sole and absolute discretion, to immediately suspend the Client’s access to, or use of, the Services (or any portion thereof), including but not limited to any associated software, APIs, support, or deliverables, without liability to the Client or any third party, upon the occurrence of any of the following events (each a "Suspension Event"):\n\n**(a) Delinquency in Payment.** The Client fails to pay any undisputed fees, invoices, or other charges when due, and such failure continues for a period of [five (5)] business days following the provision of written notice of such delinquency.\n\n**(b) Breach of Material Obligations.** The Company determines, in its reasonable judgment, that the Client (or its authorized users) has breached any material term of this Agreement, including but not limited to the Acceptable Use Policy, confidentiality obligations, or intellectual property restrictions.\n\n**(c) Security and Integrity Threats.** The Company determines that the Client’s use of the Services: (i) poses a security risk to the Company’s infrastructure, the Services, or any third party; (ii) may subject the Company or its affiliates to liability; (iii) is fraudulent, abusive, or unlawful; or (iv) interferes with the performance or integrity of the Services for other customers.\n\n**(d) Regulatory or Legal Requirement.** The Company is required to suspend Services to comply with any applicable law, regulation, court order, or request from a governmental or regulatory authority.\n\n**39.2. Scope and Notice.** Suspension under this Section 39 may be applied to the Client’s entire account or to specific sub-accounts, users, or Service components. The Company shall provide the Client with notice of the suspension as soon as is commercially practicable under the circumstances; provided, however, that the Company reserves the right to suspend Services without prior notice in the event of an Emergency Security Issue (defined as any situation where failure to suspend would result in immediate harm, data breach, or system instability).\n\n**39.3. Effect of Suspension.** During any period of suspension:\n(i) The Client’s right to access and use the Services shall cease immediately;\n(ii) All payment obligations of the Client under this Agreement shall continue to accrue and remain payable, including any recurring fees or minimum commitments;\n(iii) The Client shall not be entitled to any service level credits, refunds, or set-offs otherwise available under any Service Level Agreement (SLA); and\n(iv) The Company may, at its option, restrict access to any data or content stored within the Services, provided that the Company shall not be obligated to delete such data during the suspension period unless the Agreement is subsequently terminated.\n\n**39.4. Reinstatement of Services.** The Company shall reinstate the Services only after the Client has: (a) cured the breach or condition that gave rise to the suspension to the Company’s reasonable satisfaction; (b) paid all outstanding arrears, including any late payment interest and reasonable administrative costs incurred by the Company in connection with the suspension; and (c) provided adequate assurances, if requested by the Company, of future compliance with the terms of this Agreement. A reinstatement fee of $[Amount] may be assessed at the Company’s discretion as a condition of restoring access.\n\n**39.5. Limitation of Liability and Indemnification.** The Company shall not be liable for any damages, losses, expenses, or costs (including, without limitation, loss of profits, loss of data, or business interruption) that the Client or any third party may incur as a result of a suspension carried out in accordance with this Section 39. The Client agrees to indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the Company from and against any claims arising out of or related to a suspension necessitated by the Client’s breach or conduct.\n\n**39.6. Relationship to Termination.** The Company’s right to suspend Services is in addition to, and not in lieu of, its right to terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section [X] (Termination for Cause). A suspension of Services shall not be construed as a waiver of the Company’s right to terminate this Agreement for the same or subsequent events, nor shall it extend any cure periods provided elsewhere in this Agreement.\n\n***\n\n### Drafting Notes for the User:\n*   **Bracketed Items:** Note the `[five (5)]` days and `$[Amount]`—these are variables you should adjust based on your specific business requirements.\n*   **Pro-Client Mitigation:** If you are representing the Client, you would want to negotiate for "prior written notice" in all circumstances, a cap on reinstatement fees, and a requirement that the Company must "minimize the scope" of the suspension to only the affected users rather than the whole company.\n*   **Interplay with SLA:** This clause explicitly denies SLA credits during suspension, which is vital for preventing a client from claiming "downtime" credits when they were shut off for non-payment.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

## 40. Termination for Cause

[{'type': 'text', 'text': '**40. TERMINATION FOR CAUSE**\n\n**40.1. Events of Default.** Either Party (the “Non-Breaching Party”) may, without prejudice to any other rights or remedies available to it at law or in equity, terminate this Agreement in its entirety, or terminate any specific Statement of Work (SOW) then in effect, effective immediately upon written notice to the other Party (the “Breaching Party”), should any of the following events of default (each, an “Event of Default”) occur:\n\n(a) **Material Breach.** The Breaching Party commits a material breach of any term, condition, or obligation under this Agreement or any SOW, where such breach is incapable of cure, or, if capable of cure, remains uncured for a period of thirty (30) calendar days following the Breaching Party’s receipt of written notice specifying the nature of the breach and demanding cure;\n\n(b) **Repeated Breaches.** The Breaching Party persistently or repeatedly breaches the same or different obligations under this Agreement in such a manner as to reasonably justify the opinion that its conduct is inconsistent with it having the intention or ability to give effect to the terms of this Agreement, notwithstanding that such breaches, when taken individually, may not constitute a material breach or may have been cured;\n\n(c) **Insolvency and Bankruptcy.** To the extent permitted by applicable law, the Breaching Party: (i) becomes insolvent or admits its inability to pay its debts generally as they become due; (ii) becomes subject, voluntarily or involuntarily, to any proceeding under any domestic or foreign bankruptcy or insolvency law; (iii) makes a general assignment for the benefit of creditors; or (iv) has a receiver, trustee, custodian, or similar agent appointed by order of any court of competent jurisdiction to take charge of or sell any material portion of its property or business;\n\n(d) **Criminal or Fraudulent Acts.** The Breaching Party, or any of its personnel, is found to have engaged in fraud, embezzlement, misappropriation of funds, or any other criminal act in the performance of its obligations under this Agreement, or is indicted for a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude that materially impairs the Breaching Party’s ability to perform or damages the reputation of the Non-Breaching Party;\n\n(e) **Violation of Laws or Compliance.** The Breaching Party fails to comply with any applicable laws, regulations, or ordinances, including but not limited to anti-corruption laws (e.g., FCPA, UK Bribery Act), data protection regulations (e.g., GDPR, CCPA), or export control laws, and such failure results in a material adverse effect on the Non-Breaching Party;\n\n(f) **Unauthorized Assignment.** The Breaching Party attempts to assign, sublicense, or otherwise transfer any of its rights or obligations under this Agreement in violation of the anti-assignment provisions set forth in Section [X] herein.\n\n**40.2. Immediate Termination.** Notwithstanding the cure period set forth in Section 40.1(a), the Non-Breaching Party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice if the breach involves a violation of the Confidentiality (Section [X]), Intellectual Property Rights (Section [X]), or Non-Solicitation (Section [X]) provisions of this Agreement, or if the Breaching Party’s conduct poses a significant threat to the security, integrity, or stability of the Non-Breaching Party’s infrastructure or data.\n\n**40.3. Effect of Termination for Cause.** Upon termination of this Agreement for cause:\n\n(a) **Cessation of Services.** The Breaching Party shall immediately cease all performance of services and the use of any systems or materials provided by the Non-Breaching Party;\n\n(b) **Payment Obligations.** If the Non-Breaching Party is the Customer, it shall pay for all Services actually and satisfactorily performed up to the effective date of termination, provided that the Customer may withhold from such payment any amounts necessary to offset damages, costs, and expenses incurred as a result of the Event of Default. If the Non-Breaching Party is the Provider, all unpaid fees for Services rendered through the date of termination shall become immediately due and payable;\n\n(c) **Return of Property.** Each Party shall, within ten (10) business days, return to the other Party or, at the other Party’s option, destroy and certify the destruction of all Confidential Information, materials, documentation, and property belonging to the other Party in its possession or control;\n\n(d) **Step-In Rights.** In the event of a termination resulting from the Provider’s default, the Customer shall have the right, but not the obligation, to assume the performance of the Services itself or engage a third party to do so. The Provider shall cooperate fully in the transition of such Services and shall be liable for any reasonable excess costs incurred by the Customer in procuring substitute services.\n\n**40.4. Remedies Cumulative.** The right of termination under this Section 40 is not an exclusive remedy. The Non-Breaching Party shall be entitled to pursue all other remedies available under this Agreement, at law, or in equity, including but not limited to seeking injunctive relief and the recovery of compensatory and consequential damages (subject to the Limitation of Liability provisions in Section [X]).\n\n**40.5. Survival.** Any provision of this Agreement which, by its nature, is intended to survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement shall survive, including but not limited to Section 40.3 (Effect of Termination), Section [X] (Confidentiality), Section [X] (Indemnification), and Section [X] (Limitation of Liability).\n\n**40.6. Waiver of Breach.** The failure of the Non-Breaching Party to exercise its right to terminate for cause upon the occurrence of an Event of Default shall not constitute a waiver of such right or a waiver of any subsequent Event of Default.', 'extras': {'signature': ''}}]

otherwise deemed unable to pay its debts under any applicable bankruptcy or insolvency legislation;\n(b) commences a voluntary case or other proceeding seeking liquidation, reorganization, arrangement, adjustment, protection, or composition of its debts under any law relating to bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, or relief of debtors, or seeks the appointment of a receiver, trustee, custodian, conservator, or other similar official for itself or for any substantial part of its property;\n(c) has an involuntary case or other proceeding commenced against it seeking
